charity.description:
At Macmillan, we will move mountains to help people with cancer live life as fully as they can.

We’re doing whatever it takes. But without your help we can’t support everyone who needs us. To
donate, volunteer, raise money or campaign with us, call 0300 1000 200 or visit macmillan.org.uk

story:
Thanks for supporting my fundraising.  At Macmillan, we give people with cancer everything we’ve got. If you’re diagnosed, your worries are our worries. We’re doing whatever it takes. But without your help we can’t support everyone who needs us.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs.

eventName: Polo's Big Walk for Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
We're a few days late but I'm confident me and Polo can still make it to 100km before the end of November. Hopefully the weather will be on our side as Mr "I'm from Spain, I don't do rain" is hard to motivate sometimes. But his raincoat is ready and the apple watch is on (me, not him) and we're ready to go!

Thanks for supporting my fundraising. You can find more information about Macmillan Cancer Support here https://www.macmillan.org.uk/ 

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs.

At Macmillan, we will move mountains to help people with cancer live life as fully as they can.

charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Since losing mom in April 2020 I’ve wanted to give something back to the amazing Macmillan nurses who supported her right from diagnosis to death. They were not only there for mom, but also for me and my brother, who at times couldn’t see the woods for the trees. They helped with every aspect of caring for someone who is terminally ill, from filling out forms to speaking to drs and to being a constant form of support to us all. 

They showed compassion beyond our expectations and I honestly don’t know how we would have got through this most challenging time without them, even more so it was during the pandemic. 

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

It is so important Macmillan can continue their work and be there for all of us who have to face watching someone we love be diagnosed with terminal cancer.
title: Fundraising for Macmillan

story: Welcome to my Just Giving fundraising page! I am running the 2022 Edinburgh Half Marathon for Macmillan Cancer Support in order to raise as much money as possible. This charity lies very close to my family, as my Grandma has spent most of her life fundraising for Macmillan, which has inspired the rest of the family to take part in money-raising activities. There have been many people around me affected by cancer, so this is a way to help an amazing charity who help them. I would be so grateful if you could take the time to sponsor me to help the cause and to motivate me in my training!

story:
We are holding our Christmas event this year on Saturday 13th November. For anyone that cannot make it to the salon on the day (or prior to our raffle draw), we’ve an online donation option right here! 

As with previous years, all proceeds will go to Macmillan Cancer Support. 

It's safe to say Macmillan have cared for so many of our loved ones when faced with cancer. This year more than ever, every donation no matter how small really does matter.

We will be raising funds through until 23rd December 2021 when we will do our raffle draw. Enough time to deliver this hamper to the winner before Christmas! 

Feel free to purchase tickets in person or online via this JustGiving page.

If donating online please make sure to tick the box to share your contact details with me, so I can issue you with raffle ticket numbers. Tickets are 1 strip for £1 or 6 strips for £5, however you may donate any amount you wish.

Our hamper is still being added to, currently containing gift vouchers, skincare, candles, along with other items kindly donated from other local businesses. Value over £250.

Thank you in advance, Kerry

***********

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs.

charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story: When my eldest sister Caroline was suffering from Cancer in 2014 Macmillan provided no nonsense help and as much reassurance as was possible. They were, caring, compassionate and realistic in their help and advice which was better than anything the NHS provided. We lost her but they helped make the final few months of her life more bearable. Macmillan work entirely on donations, to the best of my knowledge, and I would like to think they would be there if anyone was in need of their services.

At Macmillan, we will move mountains to help people with cancer live life as fully as they can.

charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
Ok everyone, I have decided that instead of Violining whilst Cycling, this year I would join the thousands of people who are doing 100 squats a day during the month of November for Macmillan Cancer Support… but with a twist! Yes you guessed it - I will aim to play the violin throughout. I know, I’m completely mental!!!

This charity does so much for those suffering with cancer. I have been very fortunate not to have had it but so many people close to me have - some with amazing success stories and some not so lucky. Macmillan offer support right from the moment someone is diagnosed and no-one ever realises how much they need that support until they are in that position.

Any donation you make will be greatly appreciated and will help Macmillan to support more people affected by cancer in many ways. The following are just an example:

£5.40 will fund 10 copies of Macmillan's cancer guide.
£16 will fund Macmillan's online community for 1 hour.
£32 will fund a Macmillan Nurse for 1 hour.

Thank you all so much for your support! I’ll be going live each evening of November (with the exception of a couple of dates as I have concerts!) so put your song requests in now 😃

story:
Hi all,

Thanks for taking the time to view our page.

As some of you may know, our mum was diagnosed with breast cancer in April this year (2021) she is currently undergoing chemotherapy treatment.  So in appreciation to Macmillan and this wonderful charity we have decided to host a Coffee Afternoon.

This is a very difficult time for us all, however knowing we have the support and love around us from this amazing charity, close friends and family really does help.

If anyone would like to donate to this charity which is very close to our hearts we would really appreciate your support.

Thanks for supporting my fundraising. At Macmillan, we give people with cancer everything we’ve got. If you’re diagnosed, your worries are our worries. We’re doing whatever it takes. charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story: I have recently lost my dad, and although he didn’t have cancer the Macmillan nurses looked after him at the end of his life. My dad was a very strong person, in his youth he was a body builder, so I thought the 100 squats per day was quite fitting!!  He showed his strength at the end, so much so, that everyday the nurses came to see him at home, they were astonished daily that he was still hanging on in there. I miss him and would love to ring him to hear his voice. I think he would be proud of me, although would laugh at me moaning about my aching legs. So here’s to you dad, love you so much. Xxxxx

eventName: Loose 4 stone then ride the fastest zip line in the world!
story:
When ticking things off my bucket list I like to raise money for charities at the same time, so not only am I living my best life I’m helping others to live there’s too!! Virtually everyone has been effected by the ‘C word’ at some point in there lives wether it be themselves, a relative, friend, loosing somebody close to them. Let’s do our bit to help raise money for this amazing charity who support those who get diagnosed!! 

Me & Jade will both loose 4 stone each between now & September then face the fastest zip line in the world/the longest in Europe! Reaching speeds of over 100mph!! Please support us in our journey by donating whatever you can, no matter how little it all helps this amazing charity!!

charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Susan battled this truly awful disease for 6 years.  She was an inspiration to those who were fortunate enough to meet her.  She never lay down and she never complained.  She had a never 'give in' attitude and always had her 'positive head' on.  

Sadly, it took over quickly in the end, quicker than she and all of us could ever have imagined.  

Susan sadly lost her battle suddenly on Monday 1st November 2021.

She was an amazing wife, mother, sister and a good friend to many.

story:
I was taking part in the macmillian walk your dog 100km , unfortunately I have broken my leg badly but my dogs George and Holly are still going to walk and run for me bless them . They are participating at burts haven freedom field and tracked so we know how far they are walking they will easily rock 100 km. It runs until end of november it would be wonderful to support us 

A charity so close to our hearts as a family so please give whatever you can 50p to £500 every penny counts. 

Many thanks and much love 

Michelle George and Holly xx

story:
Thanks for supporting my fundraising. 

I am Kira, I have decided to go sugar free for the month of November. I am raising money for MacMillan as they supported my Dad when he was going through his own cancer battle. Luckily my Dad is now fit, well and cancer free. But I would to show my thanks for helping him. Anyone who knows me knows what a challenge this will be for me. So please give if you can to support this wonderful charity. Every penny really does help.

charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
Mabel is the school dog at Bemerton St John and she is an important part of school life. We are a community school and part of our vision is to 'serve others'. In recent months, we have sadly had members of our school community diagnosed with cancer; we would therefore like to raise money for Macmillan in order to support these families and those closest to them. At Macmillan, they do whatever it takes to help families in need by providing emotional and physical support, as well as any equipment which may be needed in the home.

Mabel is just over 8 months old and to reach the target of 100km, she must walk at least 3.3km every day! The children in school can help Mabel to achieve this by walking her during lunchtimes around the playground and field. 

We hope to raise as much money as possible for this amazing charity and would greatly appreciate all donations.

From the Bemerton St John team and Mabel x
title: Mabel's 100km walk!
pageSummary: Mabel is walking 100km throughout November because we want to support members of our school community

eventName: Walk 100Km with your dog in November
story: Poppy and I are walking 100km this November for Macmillan and your contribution will make an impact, whether you donate £5 or £500. Every little bit helps. Thank you for your support. Below is some information about Macmillan Cancer Support. There’s around 3 million people living with cancer in the UK today, and over 360,000 more are diagnosed every year. Right now, millions of people with cancer are counting on Macmillan for physical, financial and emotional support. At Macmillan, they do whatever it takes – last year was no exception. But they can't do it alone. Macmillan is facing a huge drop in income as a result of the coronavirus pandemic. Because 97% of their work is funded by people like us, they need our support now more than ever. Visit their website to find out more https://www.macmillan.org.uk/.

charity.description:
At Macmillan, we will move mountains to help people with cancer live life as fully as they can.

charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
When I start this walk it will be five years almost to the day that I was diagnosed with a gynaecological cancer. After noticing a sore which didn't heal my husband tried to convince me to go to the doctors. I eventually overcame my embarrassment and went, after putting it off and putting it off and then got referred to Princess Anne Hospital, Southampton. The news was then broken to me. I had cancer. My whole world seemed to fall apart. It was possible that I only had a limited time left and I would only know which way things would go after surgery.I was told I would need surgery asap and 5/6 weeks later I had surgery to remove an SCC. Fortunately it was good news and they managed to remove it all....albeit very painful and having to be bedridden for what seemed an eternity.

Macmillan were there for me from day 1 if I needed them. They provided me with all the information of my diagnosis, the treatment, prognosis and life after surgery. Macmillan were there.

Four years later I have just reduced my reviews with my consultant from 3 monthly to 6 monthly and things are looking good.

We must not be embarrassed to talk to people about problems. If I had left it much longer, things would have been very different. 

Macmillan helped with that and I would like to give something back to help others

Macmillan give people with cancer everything. If you’re diagnosed, your worries are their worries. They do whatever it takes. But without your help they can’t support everyone who needs us. Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs.

Thank you so much for supporting me with my fundraising for such a fantastic cause.
title: Nicola walks 34km along the Jurassic Coast  for Macmillan Cancer

charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
We are raising money for Macmillan Cancer in memory of our beloved Yousif Lathram. We lost Yousif to lung cancer back in November 2019. We would like to raise money for this charity in Yousif's name to help other families through this difficult journey. So we shall be walking the South Downs Half Marathon on the 12th of June, 2022 as Team Lush! (he would have agreed with and been very amused by this name :) )

Yousif was a smart man with a zest for life; he loved to dance, drink, laugh, and be silly. He was also generous and kind to everyone he met and loved all his family. Even though he had a difficult journey he maintained a brave stance until the very end for the sake of us all.

Macmillan offers emotional, physical, and financial support to families affected by cancer and we think it's one of the best cancer charities out there. Any donation you can make, no matter how small, will help to support families that are going through the same experience.

Thank you for supporting us and Macmillan Cancer Support.

With much love and thanks,

Valerie (wife), Olivia (daughter) & Miral (daughter in law)

story:
We are The FaDaS: Aurore, Matthias and Patrick, daughter, son and father, participating in 2022 Etape Lochness cycling event. This will be our first family event, first cycling event, first event abroad. To keep in the spirit of "Firsts" we thought "what's better than to turn it into a first fundraising for a noble cause?" and that's why you are reading this today, to help us in fundraising for Macmillan Cancer Support. We want to be able to enjoy our ride together, while remembering how privileged we are to be here, and giving back to the community.

charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story: After finding a lump in my breast I was diagnosed with breast cancer in 2012. After having a mastectomy and 7 months of Radiotherapy and Chemoptherapy I was finally given the all clear.  In 2014 I had a failed attempt at breast reconstruction. I tried again in 2017 thankfully it was a success. I suffered some bad side effects including fatigue, pain and hair loss.  I now feel ready to give something back to macmillan who supported me and I feel that this time it's my choice to lose my hair and I am in control. Any donations/ sponsors will be so appreciated.
title: Yaya's Brave the shave
pageSummary: I am shaving my head to raise money for Macmillan because I fought and beat breast cancer  in 2012/13

charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
I have lost friends and family to cancer. I know plenty of people that have too. It's a b@st@rd and tears lives apart. I'm grateful for those who've been touched by it and survived. 

I can't grow a tash so Movember is out of the question, and don't like running or cycling that much, so I'll be squatting my way through November to raise some money to help support those that are fighting cancer. That will be 700 squats a week and 3,000 squats in 30 days. 

Thank you for supporting my fundraising!

story:
Thanks for supporting my fundraising. At Macmillan, we give people with cancer everything we’ve got. If you’re diagnosed, your worries are our worries. We’re doing whatever it takes. But without your help we can’t support everyone who needs us.Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs.

I’ve been warming up for November’s 100 squats per day challenge! Music is loud and a lot of shouting gets me through!
A very worthy cause of course and close to my heart! I have lost two friends to cancer this year. Two other friends who have both battled as ferociously as the treatment has been to them are on the way back to reclaiming their bodies and minds. One is back running and living his life fully again! My other friend is on her way out of the ghastly stretch, regaining strength and some sense of normality or at least having a jolly good peek at it again! One day at a time… not long now girl!
Please donate as much as you feel possible, any small amount helps and I promise to complete my challenge, muscles talking and me shouting defiantly!

charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
Anybody that knows My family knows how much this charity means to us and what a tremendous help they are to many families out there dealing with the Big C.

So I am doing 100 squats a day during the month of November for Macmillan Cancer Support. If you would like to support me, any donation you make to my challenge will be greatly appreciated and will help Macmillan to support more people affected by cancer. 


Did you know that:

£5.40 could fund 10 copies of Macmillan's cancer guide, £16 could fund Macmillan's online community for 1 hour and £32 could fund a Macmillan Nurse for 1 hour.

Thank you so much for your support, we couldn't do what we do without you!

story:
Cancer has hit my family hard over the years, I lost my beloved Mom to cancer and my sister was diagnosed with breast cancer a few years ago, thankfully she is doing great and has made a full recovery but not everyone is so lucky. Anything you can give to support me in my challenge to raise as much money as possible for this great charity is greatly appreciated and it really will make a difference.

Thanks for supporting my fundraising. At Macmillan, we give people with cancer everything we’ve got. If you’re diagnosed, your worries are our worries. We’re doing whatever it takes. But without your help we can’t support everyone who needs us.Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs.

Many thanks, Steph

charity.description:
The nation’s leading first aid charity.
Every year, more than 400,000 people learn how to save a life through our training programmes.
Our volunteers provide first aid in their communities and thanks to them fewer lives will be lost needlessly. 
Raise money. Help save lives. Be the difference.
charity.name: St John Ambulance
story:
Every year I create bespoke art/installation outside my house to celebrate Christmas and raise money for a charity. This year I am helping St John Ambulance and spread some love over festive month.

You are welcome to come along to the installation to check out what I created and get a treat at the same time.

Donation can be done via this page or in person using cash or contactless.

I hope you will help me to reach my target and have a wonderful Christmas and happy new year!

You can follow us on Facebook  ( @lattimoreroad ) or on Instagram ( @lattimoreroad )
title: Christian's Lattimore Road Christmas installation

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Kier Group has selected the British Heart Foundation, the biggest independent funder of cardiovascular research in the UK, as its new corporate charity partner. The two-year partnership will help in the charitys aim of increasing awareness of cardiovascular disease, raise £250,000 for vital research in to heart and circulatory conditions as well as train 1,500 Kier colleagues in the lifesaving first aid, CPR.

The British Heart Foundation is funding life saving research to help end heartbreak for the seven million people in the UK living with cardiovascular disease. For over 50 years it has pioneered research that has transformed the lives of people living with heart and circulatory conditions and has been pivotal to offering vital treatments that are changing the fight against heart disease.
title: Kier Group and the British Heart Foundation partnership

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
eventName: Speedy’s British Heart Foundation 60th Year Challenge
story: Thanks for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support. The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. Thanks!

It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. story:
On Sunday 31st October we lost my father Mark a happy kind and generous man in the prime of his life to a sudden and unexpected heart attack. His untimely death has left a void in the lives of everyone he met, a void that can never be filled. 

As a family we would like to raise money and awareness that a tragedy like this can happen to anyone. Your donations can help research and treatments so that no other family has to go through the pain and loss we’re feeling right now. 

Love you dad your kiddo Emily ❤️

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Thanks for visiting my page. 

My Granddad was one of the fundamental cornerstones of my life. He was the unmoveable, unshakeable rock and I genuinely thought he was indestructible. Sadly this was not the case and I am still trying to come to terms with the situation. I am grateful to have spent 40 years getting to know this remarkable man, particularly as he had suffered a couple of heart attacks when I was much younger. I miss my granddad a huge amount and hopefully, the money raised will allow other grandchildren to spend more quality time with a relative in the future 

Whenever I spoke to him he would ask if I was still running and what "bloody stupid" idea I had cooked up next. The Green 26.2 mile race is a marathon inside a Victorian prison in Shepton Mallet that involves 70+laps around the corridors and in and out of the exercise yard and even up and down a large number of stairs inside the prison. It certainly won't be a fast course and I expect my legs to be shredded afterwards. 

I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support. The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. Thanks!

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
We appreciate that a lot of people have asked about sending flowers for grandads funeral. We are only having flowers from mum,  dad and nanny. 

Instead of sending flowers we are asking for donations to the British Heart Foundation a charity that is close to our hearts. 

Grandad had battled with heart disease for the last 30 years and every year told us it was his last but he kept going. The British Heart Foundation carry out amazing research which had kept grandad here and also keeps dad here! 

If anyone would like to donate instead of sending flowers please donate here as it goes straight to the British Heart Foundation. 

Thank you 

The Beach family xx

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Gerry was born and raised in Nottingham and lived his whole life here. 

He was a head teacher who dedicated many years (stretching well into his retirement) to the Nottingham Schools' Football Association, for which he received an MBE from the Queen in 2010.

He was a loving husband, father and grandfather, with many friends.

Gerry passed away on 1st November 2021 after a short spell in hospital, he was 84 years old.

We chose to honour his memory with donations to the British Heart Foundation as the work of this charity is particularly relevant to the Mills family history.

Thank you

Val, Kieren and Dominic

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Thank you for visiting my page.   I am a Static Site Engineer working for BAM FM at Crawley Schools, and will be taking on the Coast to Coast challenge to raise money for the British Heart Foundation.

The Coast to Coast walk is one of the most iconic long-distance walks in England.  I will be completing the 293km distance by a mixture of running, rowing, cycling and walking with my wife. I will be running on the streets of Crawley, and the remaining will be done in the BAM FM gyms at Ifield and Oriel.

The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. Thanks!

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Thanks for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support.  As many of you will know we lost our Mum to a heart attack in June this year and as part of my grieving process I decided to sign up to walk 100 miles in October for Breast Cancer research. I found this hard, especially in bad weather, but very therapeutic and In memory of my wee Mum, I have decided to continue my walk into November and use it to fundraise for the BHF. I would be very grateful for any amount you could kindly donate, however small,  knowing this may help save others in the future. We also lost my Dad to a heart attack, who passed  at a very young age therefore it is vitally important to support this cause to save others. Please note I will post updates regularly on my Facebook page. 

The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. Thanks!

story:
Corptel are holding a fantastic Christmas Raffle with some amazing prizes available. The prize draw is open to everyone and a donation of £5 gets you a single entry.

Over 12 days of Christmas (1st December to 16th December) Corptel will be raffling off a new prize each day. 

The prizes include;

  • 2 x VIP Tickets to a match of your choice at Manchester Utd
  • 2 x VIP Tickets to a match of your choice at Manchester City
  • 2 x Tickets to and event of your choosing at the Manchester Arena
  • EPOS Adapt wireless headphones
  • Jabra Elite 65t headphones
  • Jabra Elite 75t wireless headphones
  • £150 towards a meal for 2
  • £100 high street shopping vouchers

For more information on the prizes and how to enter, please visit....

story:
Buy your ticket to be in with the chance of winning one of the twenty spaces for breakfast with Santa for your child. One ticket is £5. Please take a photo or forward your receipt to bhflewisandharris@gmail.com so that we can contact you if you win.

20 lucky children will get the chance to have a very special festive breakfast with Santa at The County Hotel at 0930am on Saturday 11th December.

Winners will be drawn on Saturday 27th Nov and winners will be notified.

The proceeds of this event will go to The British Heart Foundation to fund vital research into heart & circulatory disease.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
BHF Chase the Pud 2021 - York Knavesmire Sunday 12 December

I started running (via Couch to 5k) in September 2020, as I wanted to do something positive to kick back against the approach of shortening days, another impending lockdown, a weird Christmas and a winter of working at home alone. I was nearly 39 and I'd never run before. Just over a year later, I now usually try and run 10k at least twice a week. 

I have never taken part in an organised race, and want to do so before the year is out. This one is close to my house, is short, raises money for a great cause, and I am doing it dressed as Santa.

2021 is the BHF's 60th anniversary so I am hoping to raise (just) £60 by running 6 (not 60!) k. (The race is only 3k or 6k so I can't opt to run any further!). If you could spare a couple of quid that would be ace.

Santas wanted for 'pud chase' at Knavesmire in York | York Press

Thanks for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support. The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. Thanks!

story:
Let's celebrate Christmas in style at THE EDINBURGH ARMS  in aid of a fabulous charity, The British Heart Foundation in memory of a beautiful lady Kathleen Johnson.

Let's dance around the Xmas tree with great music, plenty of beer & surrounded by good friends.

charity.description: The ability to get around is vital in order to live a full life yet thousands of people with sight loss never leave home alone. We empower visually impaired people to do that and rely on the support of the public to fund the guide dog service.
charity.name: Guide Dogs
charity.registrationNumber: in England and Wales 209617 and Scotland SC038979
story:
Linton Crescent, Sprowston 

Christmas Lights

Wednesday 1st December 2021 - 4..30 PM

A special visitor, Father Christmas will be at:

33 Linton Crescent. Sprowston.
There will be lots to see as you stroll along the crescent.

Linton Crescent have been fundraising for many years for many worthwhile charities, causes with their amazing Christmas lights.  

Celebrating Guide Dogs 90th Anniversary and a cause relevant to local residents too.

Please Donate:

This Christmas, help us all give a life-changing gift to someone with sight loss.Together we could fund 12 new guide dog partnerships. Each guide dog could give someone with sight loss the gift of confidence to get out and about safely. Whether helping their owner visit family or friends, or to shop for that special surprise gift for a loved one. Your fundraising will help provide life-changing practical support not just at Christmas, but all year round.From enjoying every magical Christmas moment, to the simple festive pleasures that most people take for granted. Our ambition is a future where everyone with sight loss is able to live the life they choose.Thank you.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. story: I did my first swim 7 years ago when I was diagnosed with MS. I had a new hip 5 months ago due to osteo arthritis and want to celebrate my increased mobility by swimming again and this time to raise the money for The Guide Dog Charity who I have supported in the past by fostering their working dogs in an emergency. story:
In 2017 (the year of my 40th) I was diagnosed with pigmentary glaucoma in both eyes!  This year I’ve been told I have cataracts!  I’m only 44 so pretty young to have just one of these conditions let alone both.  I’m almost certain I’ll be fine!  I’ve already had laser eye surgery to help with pain and pressure, I’ll have surgery to replace the lenses and I’ll be on medication for life but it makes me realise how lucky I am………..

Almost two million people in the UK are living with sight loss that has a significant impact on their daily lives. Of those, around 180,000 rarely leave their homes alone and lead lonely, isolated lives. Guide Dogs works for a world where people with sight loss are never left out of life, for a world where being blind or partially sighted is not what defines you. A world with enough support to make the challenges of sight loss no barrier to fulfilling hopes and dreams.

And who doesn’t love a dog 🐕💙💛 #TeamGuideDogs

eventName: 500,000 steps for Great Ormand Street Hospital Children’s Charity
story:
Throughout November I will be walking 500,000 steps to raise money for Great Ormand Street Hospital and Charity, this works out ok average about 16,666 steps a day! 

Great Ormand Street Hospital and Charity is an incredible charity. Great Ormond Street Hospital receives 237,908 outpatient visits and 43,218 inpatient visits every year (figures from 2018/19). Most of the children we care for are referred from other hospitals throughout the UK and overseas. There are 63 different clinical specialties at GOSH; the UK's widest range of specialist health services for children on one site. More than half of our patients are referred to us from outside London and a small proportion come from overseas. 

Please donate for this great cause snd support me on my steps 😊 I will also have a fundraising live on Facebook and keeping you all updated daily with my steps. 


Thank you for all your support ❤️

charity.name: Great Ormond Street Hospital Children's Charity
story:
A few hours into my life I was diagnosed with Craniosynostosis. This is the term for when the skull fuses together prematurely, before brain growth. My skull was fixed in a ridge at the top, which meant it had none of the flexibility of a normal newborn's skull. There was a likelihood that I would be brain-damaged, and have both sight and hearing impairments. Luckily, I was a Caesarian birth (because of complications at the birth of my older brother). This ended up being a blessing in disguise: if I had travelled down the birth canal, my bones wouldn't have crossed over, meaning that my eye sockets would probably have been crushed, and my nose and forehead would have collapsed.

A brain scan showed that my brain had luckily not been damaged and it would grow normally. After three months of tests it was also clear that I had no hearing or sight defects. However my parents were still stuck with the decision of what to do about the shape of my head. It looked fine as a baby - a little pointed; but as I grew it would grow too, and because of the fusion, it would grow abnormally. At 5 months old I spent a week in Great Ormond Street Hospital (one of two places in the country that specialise in Craniosynostosis) to undergo an operation which consisted of cutting across from ear to ear so that the whole chunk of bone that was fused could be cut through, and then the front and back would be pushed together to rebuild the part that had been fused. I went for consistent check ups up until the age of 18 months - which is when my parents were told that, other than the scar going across the length of my head, I will be fine. All thanks to the amazing work from the doctors at Great Ormond Street Hospital.

I’m running the London Landmarks Half Marathon on April 3rd in aid of The Great Ormond Street Hospital Charity, an extraordinary hospital which has always depended on charitable support to give seriously ill children the best chance to fulfil their potential. If you would like to donate to my fundraising for this wonderful cause, please do so above! EM x

story:
As most of you are aware in 2016 Amy just 7 years old at the time was diagnosed with a rare childhood cancer called Rhabdomyosarcoma. After having surgery, 9 cycles of intense chemotherapy and 32 rounds of proton beam radiation therapy and 30 mri's over the last 5 years Amy is in remission and about to be released from her oncologist team and over to the late effects team at GOSH. 

Amy is now 12 and has decided to celebrate this HUGE milestone by raising funds for GOSH and donating her hair to the Little Princess Trust as her way of saying thank you for all their help and support over the last 5 1/2 years. 

On Wednesday 10th November Amy is booked in to the hairdressers for a major chop. Please consider donating to her cause and help her celebrate this milestone. 

Thank you x

Lots of love from our warrior Amy and her family x

story:
My 8yr old daughter Tessa was born with an extremely rare syndrome called B.A.M. At the time of her birth she was only 1 of 42 cases recorded in medical history. To sum it up she was born without a nose.
Link to her FB page.. https://www.facebook.com/bornwithoutanose/

Since she was 18 months we have been travelling to G.O.S.H (Great Ormond Street Hospital) in London, where the brilliant doctors have been doing what they can to help her. She has had over 12 surgeries there.
The first she had was the first time ever in the world that it had been done.

Please follow my daughter's journey:

https://www.facebook.com/bornwithoutanose/

Through-out the month of November I will be doing 500,000 steps to raise money for Great Ormond Street Hospital and Children’s Charity, the hospital that saved my brothers life 12 years ago. The amazing staff who took care of Louie and in particular a surgeon by the name of Paolo De Coppi is the reason I’d like to help raise money so as this amazing facility can help to take care of the children in need.

My brother Louie suffered a severe case of septicaemia and because of Great Ormond Street we can thank them for the reason that he is still here today.

Thank you for your support. I've included information about Great Ormond Street Hospital and Children's Charity below.

Every day brings new challenges at Great Ormond Street Hospital (GOSH). Every day, 619 children and young people from across the UK arrive for life-changing treatments.

Great Ormond Street Hospital Children's Charity raises money to enable the hospital to provide world class care and to pioneer new treatments and cures for childhood illnesses.

Any donation is greatly appreciated xx

Ps This is the same fundraiser as the one on my Facebook page!!

story:
This is a challenge set by Evolve Hartlepool as a team of 2 we have 44 hours to cover 566 miles (Riding, Rowing and Running) Ride 327 miles to dover, row 31 miles to Calais, ride 182 to Paris, run 31 miles to the Eiffel tower and climb 1665 steps to the top. 

All for a fantastic cause, every penny counts. Thank you

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

You may be aware that our Nephew Henry was very poorly when he was born in September 2020. Great Ormond Street Hospital provided care and lifesaving surgery, so I am running the London Landmarks half marathon on 3rd April 2022 to raise vital funds to keep their good work going.

Henry's story.

Henry was born at 34 weeks and initially seemed healthy and well. He stopped breathing when he was 2 days old and was diagnosed at the time with laryngomacia caused by his prematurity.

When Henry was 6 weeks old he had his first respiratory arrest at home, requiring rescue breaths from his mum and his first trip to hospital via ambulance. He went on to have multiple respiratory arrests and trips to hospital, having to be resuscitated by his mum on 2 more of those occasions. 

Following an appointment with his paediatric consultant, Henry was referred to the John Radcliffe hospital in Oxford for further tests on his heart. Whilst waiting for his appointment he had a further respiratory arrest at home and was transferred by ambulance directly to Oxford. Flowing scans and x-rays, the cardiac team diagnosed a vascular ring compressing his trachea and oesophagus, this was caused by him having been born with a double aortic arch. He was transferred to GOSH, to have an excision of his left arch and Kommerell's diverticulum.

Surgeons stated the compression of his windpipe was very severe, as it was less than 1mm in diameter and he was lucky to have survived. 

Henry seemed well after his surgery but was rushed back to hospital a week after his discharge following another respiratory arrest and resuscitation at home. He had another arrest at hospital, requiring immediate treatment. Henry was transferred back to GOSH where they found he would need further surgery to release adhesions of the Left Subclavian Artery and an Aortopexy. 

During his last procedure, the surgeon had to remove his Thymus gland to perform the Aortopexy. His parents agreed to donate this as children born without one die before they are 2 years old. They were delighted to hear that it had been successfully transplanted into a baby this year.
Henry had to remain in hospital until he'd had this surgery, resulting in weeks in London away from family during a pandemic and lockdown.

Henry was finally discharged after successful surgery and has made a full recovery. His gross motor movements are a little delayed due to months of debilitation and he continues to be closely monitored to ensure the growth of his windpipe and oesophagus. 


Henry is now a happy, healthy and energetic one year old. We will be forever grateful that the cardiac team at GOSH were able to save Henry, without them he would not be here with us now!

charity.description: We fundraise to enhance Great Ormond Street Hospital’s ability to transform the health and wellbeing of children and young people. Donations help to fund advanced medical equipment, child and family support services, pioneering research and rebuilding and refurbishment.
charity.name: Great Ormond Street Hospital Children's Charity
story:
I am running the London Landmarks Half Marathon on Sunday 3rd April with my dad, Chris and my sister, Louisa. We have decided to run for 3 separate charities that are close to our hearts. 

I have decided to run for Great Ormond Street Hospital, a hospital that treats childhood illnesses. The hospital receives over 230,000 outpatient visits and over 40,000 inpatient visits annually. This world-class hospital helps find new treatments through continuous research. 

This run is in memory of my beautiful friend Addie Brady, who sadly lost her battle to a brain tumour in 2018. 

In 2011, Addie was diagnosed with a rare form of bone cancer called spindle cell sarcoma. She underwent surgery that removed her tibia bone and was replaced with a titanium metal. All was well and Addie continued with her life, grateful for things getting back to normal. 

However, in 2016 when Addie was at a family party she appeared to be in a trance like state. This was followed by a number of seizures in the ambulance whilst she was being rushed to hospital. From there, she was transferred to Great Ormond Street Hospital to discover an aggressive, high grade, inoperable tumour. To everyone’s surprise this was unrelated to the first cancer. Addie was diagnosed Li-Fraumeni Sydnrome also known as LFS, an inherited familial predisposition. LFS occurs due to a mutation in a tumour suppressor gene called TP53. Addie was given 12-18 months to live. Despite Addie and her family’s urge to find more extensive treatment, there was nothing in or outside the UK. 

Addie underwent radiotherapy and chemotherapy and remained stable for just over a year. However, it became aggressive very quickly. After more scans, they found that the tumour had spread to her spine. This took over her mobility, sight and mind. 

Addie unfortunately passed away on 1st February 2018 in her home at the age of 16.

Addie was the most extraordinary, beautiful, crazy and loving girl. She is loved and missed by everyone everyday. Her laugh was infectious and her smile lit up the room. Memories I made with Addie will never leave, I do not know anyone that made me laugh as much as she did. I am so thankful that she came into my life and had such a great impact, as she did with everyone that she met. 

Through fundraising for this run, it will help other people like Addie. This care is vital through the hardest days of their lives. Every penny counts. 

Thank you in advance, Helena xxx

story:
As someone who doesn't enjoy running at the best of times, this should be interesting!

Following an unsuccessful application last year, I am delighted to be running the London Marathon this year, especially for such a great cause.

I chose to run for GOSH because of the great work they do, which my family felt first-hand when they saved my brother's life back in 2002.

Those close to me will know how much of a task this will be for me to complete, considering I (allegedly) cannot complete a 5km in a decent time, let alone 42.2!

If you can spare a donation or simply a share of this page, I would greatly appreciate it and hopefully, I will see you there on the day :)

Below is a bit more about GOSH if you are unfamiliar with charity.

Every day, 619 children and young people from across the UK arrive at GOSH. Every day, doctors and nurses battle the most complex illnesses, and the brightest minds come together to achieve pioneering medical breakthroughs. And every day is a chance for you to make a difference. This extraordinary hospital has always depended on charitable support and everyone in Team GOSH taking on the iconic 2022 London Marathon will be helping to give seriously ill children the chance of a better future. For more information about the work GOSH does and to find out where Team GOSH's fundraising will go visit the website: https://www.gosh.org/what-we-do

eventName: Gaming week in aid of Cancer Research UK
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Throughout my life, myself and my family like many others have been devastated by the effects that Cancer has had on people. Personally I have lost my Auntie Yvonne and my cousin Emma to this horrible disease, both taken long before their time was up. 

I am spending a week dedicating my gaming streams on Facebook to both Yvonne and Emma, and everyone out there who has been/are currently being effected by Cancer. 

Me doing this is just a small drop in a massive ocean, but doing something I enjoy whilst hopefully raising money for an amazing charity is what its all about. Cancer Research UK are doing amazing work in the battle against Cancer and helping all those people effected by it. 

Any donation you can give is a massive help to a future hopefully without cancer. Thank You.   

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

story:
THE L200 CANCER RELAY

Ok... been thinking about doing a charity event for quite some time now.. something that members of the l200 groups could get involved with.. so I've come up with something like a relay race only we use a bear instead of a baton.. the idea is that the bear stays a day or 2 with 1 member at a time and gets an action picture of the bear doing something like take it to work or have it sat on your truck.. maybe fixing your engine 🙈 be creative .. then that picture will be uploaded to the fb page I will setup so its journey can be documented.. then driven to the next member and so on.. overland journey make take upto a month or 2 who knows.

Also a sanitizer spray will also go with him so he dont catch covid or spread it 🙄

Thanks from the admin team ✌

Siobhan & Sylda

charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
As you know Dad passed away at Marie Curie hospice in August where they helped him rest peacefully and looked after us as a family exceptionally well.

Therefore we decided to set ourselves a target of paying back Marie Curie for the 14 nights Dad was with them and over the next year we would like to raise a total of £6144 to pay for a day at the hospice next summer.

Over the year we are all going to take on challenges and host events to raise money for this amazing charity.


I am starting the fundraising by joining the current Marie Curie challenge to run 60 miles in November.

Marie Curie are currently helping me through a rough patch by providing free counselling and support which I'm very appreciative of.

I'm hoping by getting myself out of the house and active for 2+ miles a day this will also help me on my journey to feeling more positive and living my life to the full again.


Please donate anything that you can. All donations are greatly appreciated!

charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
5 years ago a good friend of mine, Ben, lost his fight with cancer. He was in his early forties and left behind three young children and a loving wife. A few weeks later I also lost my Gran to the same disease. This month we lay to rest Dawn, another friend taken way too soon by Cancer. The purpose of this stream is to raise money for the Marie Curie charity. Providing support and care to those suffering with terminal illness, Marie Curie bring light in the darkest hours

Cancer effects us all, whether it's our family, friends or even you. At some point in all our lives cancer will strike. By donating you can make a difference and save lives.

charity.name: Marie Curie
eventName: Choose a Challenge Everest Base Camp 2022
story:
This year I'm joining a group of Aberdeen University students and Choose a Challenge in raising money for Marie Curie. Marie Curie is a charity that provides care and support to people with terminal illnesses and their families. 

In August 2022 we will be flying to Nepal and over the following 15 days we'll begin trekking from the lower slopes of the Himalayas, up (most of) Mount Everest and back down again, all in aid of Marie Curie.

Obviously, this will be hugely challenging but Marie Curie do really incredible work and the donations that they receive allow them to care for over 40,000 terminally ill people each year completely free of charge. They provide absolutely essential support to terminally ill people and their families but they rely entirely on kindness and generous donations to survive so any money that you could spare would be really appreciated and would allow them to continue to provide their care.

charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
This is the JustGiving page, set up in memory of Dominque.

Dominique was one of the bravest people we will ever know. Being diagnosed with Leukaemia just under a year ago, she was determined to fight this terrible illness. She remained courageous and positive throughout her gruelling treatment. She even defied the medics for over 3 months and we spent a lovely summer together. Sadly, on Wednesday 20th October, she lost her battle and passed away peacefully with her family around her. We miss her very much.

We kindly ask that instead of buying flowers for her funeral, donations are made to our chosen charity: Marie Curie.

Marie Curie have supported us throughout this difficult time. We would like to do something positive during our time of sadness and would therefore be very grateful for any donations made to help us raise money for this wonderful charity.

Thank you very much for your support.

Stephanie, Frederic, Nicky, Louis, Ollie & Hannah x

eventName: Great Birmingham Run (10k and Half Marathon) 2022
story:
My Nanny was someone quite special, always with a smile on her face and a truly loving heart. Sadly, on the 10th October 2021, she faced one battle too many, following years of heart troubles and myeloma, and she passed away.

Thankfully, in those tough final days she was in as much comfort as possible the whole time thanks to the incredible work of the district nurse, the NHS and, arguably most importantly, the Marie Curie nurses. Quite simply they were superb and did everything they could to make her as comfortable and pain free as possible.

To thank them for their incredible work, I have decided to dust off my running shoes, after some three years since my last half marathon, and run the Great Birmingham Run half marathon.

The work these guys do is utterly stunning and they treated her with dignity and care the whole time. Please give what you are able, any and all donations will help them to continue this brilliant work.
title: Great Birmingham Run for Nanny

eventName: Everest Base Camp Trek 2022 - Choose a Challenge
story:
Hi, 

Dan here :) 

This year. 

Maybe…

Maybe this year is showing us that, even if we endure a global uncertainty, a profound sense of hope guides us every morning as we get up from bed. Maybe this year is showing us that even though plans can divert and dreams can take a different kind of wing, we are still willing to fight and adapt. Maybe this year is showing us that even if we feel alone, we are not alone and, a pandemic can't distance us from one another. Maybe this year, we have turned our losses into lessons. Maybe this year, we have realised how strong, brave and human we really are. 

Personally, this year, I was undertaking my studies in medical school through lockdown and a pandemic, away from family and dear friends. Yet, I couldn’t fathom the reality that things could skew drastically. My grandmother, Maria passed away in spring and I couldn't be...there... due to travel restrictions. My grandfather, Petru, stepped out of this world into another kind of beautiful, five months later. 

Next year, in memory of my grandmother and grandfather, on 29th August 2022, I will be flying off all the way to Nepal to take part in a Choose a Challenge trek for 15 days through the Himalayan mountains up to Everest Base Camp (5,364 metres – altitude sickness starts kicking in around 2,500 metres – generally…). Undoubtedly, it will be a challenge however I can’t ignore what happened this year and I would like to take this as an opportunity to fundraise for a charity dear to my heart. 

The charity I have chosen to fundraise for is Marie Curie. 

Marie Curie is the UK’s leading end of life charity. They provide frontline nursing and hospice care, a free support line and a wealth of information and support on all aspects of dying, death and bereavement. 

Marie Curie speaks and provides a compassionate level of care to people affected by terminal illness. Losing somebody close affects everyone in distinct ways. Everyone’s different, so it’s not easy to say exactly what will happen when the end of someone’s life gets closer. However, Marie Curie aims to be in those moments every step of the way. 

In total, Marie Curie will receive AT LEAST £1,695 from this fundraiser. Here is a perspective of what all your donations could help with:

- Could provide nursing support to 9 people living with terminal illness in their homes through the night, bringing the expert care and comfort families need.

- Could pay for 85 vital hours of nursing care from a Marie Curie Nurse for someone living with terminal illness. 

- Could help fund research into better ways of caring for people with a terminal illness and influence health and social care policies to provide the highest quality care and support, when and where it is needed. 

- Could help provide much needed support for families and friends.

We picked up many experiences this year. 

Any donations, no matter how small, will make a great impact in someone else’s life who is battling a terminal illness. 

Maybe this year, we can show that we aren’t alone and that we need each other.

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

story:
Welcome to the Jubilee Swan's Just Giving page. 

RNLI was picked as our 2021/22 charity of choice. 

Through the year all the money we raise at events and socials will go directly to the RNLI via this page. 

Open water swimming as a sport has seen an massive increase in popularity since 2019 so supporting RNLI feels fitting for our small band of swans. 

From RNLI: 

Too many people are still drowning. More than ever we need the RNLI’s help. As a charity, the RNLI depends on our donations so it can go on saving lives and keeping us and our loved ones safe. RNLI lifesavers are our lifeline. They’re the lifeboat crews who provide 24-hour search and rescue right around the UK and Ireland. The lifeguards keeping watch on 240 of the busiest beaches in the UK and Channel Islands. And the RNLI safety teams and educators working tirelessly to stop people getting into trouble in the first place.

Thank you.

story:
Thank you for visiting our raffle page to win a St Andrews Day Hamper, please include your name when you make payment for your tickets. £5 per entry. Multiple/larger payments will be allocated a corresponding number of entries.  Entries close on Saturday the 27th of November. The raffle will be drawn on 30th November 2021.

About RNLI:

In the UK and Ireland alone, 140 people die by accident in the water each year. Half of those who drown never intend on entering the water. These are wasted lives; preventable deaths. And this needs to change.The RNLI is the charity that saves lives at sea. Last year, brave volunteer crew across Scotland launched to the rescue of people in danger 1,071 times; thats 3 launches each and every day of the year. Why? Because RNLI lifeboat crews are determined to save every one.As a charity, the RNLI receives no government funding and needs to raise an average £155,000 per year to run just one lifeboat station each year. With 46 lifeboat stations in Scotland, the RNLI needs our support to power its lifesaving service.

charity.name: RNLI - Royal National Lifeboat Institution
story:
Celebrating the life and commitment to the fishing community of Looe, our Michael Hood who sadly passed away will be fondly remembered and sorely missed by everyone who knew him and crossed paths with him. The community of Looe, his family and friends , have lost a diamond, wonderful friend, a  fishermen of the Cornish sea. Mick was a kind,  gentleman and made any person feel comfortable in his presence. His patience and wisdom teaching beginners and helping keen fishermen to reel in their catch and bait up always came with wise words of how to catch the "big one" along with lots of banter allowing each person on the boat feeling confident the next bite was the catch of the day. An experienced fishing mentor who shared many stories and experiences with the next person.

As beautiful as any flower can be, there's no color, or big enough size of flower to personify Mick's passing, so we have decided to raise funds and collect donations to go towards the RNLI  fund so Mick's legendary life can live on and continue to be remembered and celebrated. By donating towards the RNLI fund  we will continue to support all the wonderful traits Mick displayed and believed in. To help your fellow man, to be safe at sea, to enjoy and appreciate the wonderful ocean with respect of it's natural force. To be kind, caring and to share what the beauty of the ocean can give to man. Your RNLI donation would be greatly appreciated in lieu of flowers and we continue to honour Mick and our beautiful shores.

In 2010 the D-Class Inshore Lifeboat Ollie Naismith was officially named and went on service at Looe. The lifeboat was named after a popular local teenager Ollie Naismith who sadly died in a tragic road traffic accident in 2009. Ollies parents, Maxine and John Naismith spearheaded a fundraising campaign to raise the funds for the lifeboat which has gone on to save many lives in and around Looe including the life of Louis Webber, a young local lad who was of a similar age to Ollie. The lifeboat is now coming to the end of its operational life so the team at Looe Lifeboat station are teaming up with the Naismiths and Webber family to launch the Looe Lifeboat Appeal to raise the £78,000 required to provide a replacement lifeboat which will be named the Ollie Naismith II.Your donation to this community appeal will help to fund this lifeboat which will continue the selfless work of our volunteer lifeboat crew in Looe.
title: In Loving memory of Micky
pageSummary: Raising money for the new Looe Lifeboat because It was a cause that meant a lot to Micky.

charity.description:
We’re the world’s leading independent conservation organisation. And we’re building a future where people and nature thrive together. 

That’s why we’re passionate about sharing the planet’s resources more sustainably, tackling climate change and protecting endangered wildlife.
charity.name: WWF-UK
story:
WWF is at the heart of global efforts to address the world’s most important environmental challenges: safeguarding the natural world, tackling climate change and enabling people to use only their fair share of natural resources. Together we can build a future where people and nature thrive.

Your support is much appreciated.

Find out more by visiting wwf.org.uk

charity.name: WWF-UK
story:
This year I've decided to set myself an ambitious goal. I'll be taking part in the Colombia Lost City Trek in aid of WWF. I'll be undertaking this challenging 5-day trek through the jungle to reach the ancient ruins of the Lost City. 

My challenge will support WWF, who are the world's leading independent conservation organisation with the mission to create a world where people and wildlife can thrive together. I'm supporting WWF because we are the first generation that knows we are destroying the world and the last that can do anything about it. Our planet is suffering but together we can make a difference and fight for our world.  

That is why any donation big or small, sharing my fundraising page, or even just spreading awareness of WWF is hugely appreciated! 

Thank you for all your support. 

If you'd like to find out any more information or join the fight for our world please visit https://www.wwf.org.uk/

charity.description:
We’re the world’s leading independent conservation organisation. And we’re building a future where people and nature thrive together. 

That’s why we’re passionate about sharing the planet’s resources more sustainably, tackling climate change and protecting endangered wildlife.
charity.name: WWF-UK
story:
In the past, I have been so incredibly lucky to travel to and volunteer at some of the worlds most incredible places from Chengdu Giant Panda Research Base to The Galápagos Islands. Sustainability and conservation is so vitally important if humans and nature are to continue to live in harmony, but you don’t have to go across the globe to make a difference. Next April, I am running Kew Gardens 10K to raise money for The World Wildlife Fund. 10K might not seem far, but for a novice runner, it is in incredibly daunting and a huge challenge! If you can, please help in the race to save the planet by donating what you can on the Just Giving page above which will send the money directly to WWF-UK.

WWF is at the heart of global efforts to address the world’s most important environmental challenges: safeguarding the natural world, tackling climate change and enabling people to use only their fair share of natural resources. Together we can build a future where people and nature thrive.Your support is much appreciated.Find out more by visiting wwf.org.uk

charity.name: WWF-UK
story: IF YOU GO DOWN TO THE WOODS TODAY... You might notice theres less wildlife than there used to be. Thats because half of all UK species are in decline were losing our precious red squirrels, hedgehogs and birds at an alarming rate. By taking part in The Big Winter Wander, you and your friends and family can reconnect with our country's beautiful wildlife and help protect it. The funds you raise will help us campaign to protect wildlife here, and around the world. Nature has been there to offer us comfort during difficult times, and now its our time to give back.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit this page! We are fundraising for Animal Equality, a kind and hardworking organisation working with society, governments and companies to end cruelty to farmed animals. 

Sam is running a half marathon with minimal training, and too much confidence! 

Isobel, having recently been diagnosed with ulcerative colitis, has just started training to complete her first ever 10k.

Martin and Melanie, the old crumblies, will be tagging along for the ride (possibly via piggyback!).

All donations will be matched by an anonymous donor, so we are really grateful for your donations!

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. charity.description:
Protecting rainforest is the smartest climate action we can take, no matter where we live. 

That's why Cool Earth works to find the best ways to keep rainforest standing strong by putting the needs and rights of local people first.
charity.name: Cool Earth
story:
We’re idiots. How else could you possibly describe a father and son willing to drive 10,000 miles across the world in a car that could be generously described as the size of a shoebox?



But we have a good reason for our idiocy, or more specifically we have four good reasons. They are Cool Earth, Two Saints, Saints Foundation, and EmPower. These are the charities that we’ll be supporting by running the 2021 Mongol Rally, driving from Prague through the Balkans, Turkey, the Caucasus, across the Caspian Sea, through the ‘stans, into Mongolia before finally finishing in Russia.



We expect this madness to take about six weeks (with good luck and a fair wind). Stay posted on our blog for more details and disasters.



We have already collected £977, before gift aid, via Virgin Money Giving. Our overall target is £2,000 for the four charities.
title: Tyred and Emotional Mongol Rally 2022 - Cool Earth

charity.description: A child dies every two minutes from malaria. We are one of the world’s leading non profit organisations specialising in protecting the most vulnerable from the burden of malaria and other communicable diseases. To know more about how we spend your money and where we work, please visit our website.
charity.name: Malaria Consortium
story:
Help us reach more of these children this Christmas  with mosquito nets, with diagnostic kits, with medicine, with love.

Bring smiles and joy to families across Africa and Asia by supporting Malaria Consortium today.

$10 can help to buy a bed net to keep mosquitoes away while a child sleeps

$25 can help to buy the medicines a child needs to guard against malaria

$50 can help to train a health worker to test for malaria and provide medicines

$100 can help to equip a medical facility that can care for a community

Your gift has the power to save lives.

Malaria can be stopped. Join Malaria Consortium today as we fight against one of the world's biggest killers.

charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
story:
Thank you for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page in memory of my grandmother Felicia Akinola who passed away 6 years ago.

My late grandmother whom i'll always remember as a strong, caring and very agile woman fought through the loss of sight in one eye and eventually both eyes due to cataract but that never stopped her from caring for the people around her as she always has. Unfortunately, due to little to no knowledge around the illness by health professionals in remote parts of Nigeria - her health condition worsened due to the illness until it she passed away!

I'll always remember her as a strong and charismatic woman who even through the toughest of predicament would always smile and put others before herself. I remember how even with little to no sight in both eyes, she would insist on cooking my favourite dish whenever i went to visit her. The way she would navigate through her environment and still do things  with no help was and will always remain a long cherished memory of her to me.

Your generous donations will be to honor her memory through Sightsavers who will be able to use your donations to make surgery available to people with cataract or any other form of blind illness in Nigeria, Africa. Sightsavers aims to make it easier for people to be treated for cataracts, especially in poorer countries where surgery is not always readily available.

Please feel free to come down on the 5th of December for some snooker, table tennis games and a chance to draw on a Mercedes AMG C63 at

Tauro Design 

8, Swanscombe Business Centre, 

London Rd, Swanscombe DA10 0LH. 

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.


Thank you so much for your donation, means a lot to me. 

Ladi Michael

story:
Thanks so much for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I am acutely aware of the impending crisis manifesting in Afganistan this winter. Whatever we may feel about the political situation, the inevitable result is that countless innocent children are now facing starvation. UNICEF is sending emergency Aid to support vulnerable families and I would like to help.

Please donate £20 (or more) and  include your name/ e mail on this just giving page and I will randomly select a contributor to receive a very special commissioned portrait of their child.

I work as a portrait painter (Daisy murdoch.co.uk) predominantly painting children. If you are the lucky winner, I will photograph your child and produce a 10”x12” oil painting.

Thankyou so very much.

X Daisy  .

charity.description: Médecins Sans Frontières / Doctors Without Borders (MSF) is the world's leading medical humanitarian aid organisation. We work in over 70 countries - in conflict zones, natural disasters and epidemics. We are independent, neutral and impartial. We provide medical care where it's needed most.
charity.name: Medecins Sans Frontieres / Doctors Without Borders (MSF)
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

This year I created 31 ink drawings as part of INKTOBER2021. One drawing a day, every day of October – and no cheating – what kept me going was my plan to do this as a charity art sale for Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF). 

MSF does fantastic work providing vital medical care to people across the globe - in conflict zones, natural disasters and epidemics. 

Digital copy: £5
(this could buy dressing kits to clean war wounds)

Original artwork: £50 
(this could buy the personal protective equipment for a doctor treating ebola)

Digital copies of all 31 drawings: £100 
(this could provide a folding stretcher to help patients who have suffered emergency trauma)

You can find images of all 31 drawings and their corresponding numbers/titles in the gallery.


Art Sale - How does it work?

Digital copies:
If you wish to purchase a digital copy, just make your donation and send an email to cg.sketches@gmail.com telling me which drawing(s) you would like (number or title). I will send you a high quality PDF of the digitised drawing.

You can print your digital copy and put it up in your home, use it as a colouring page, get it printed on a t-shirt – what you do with it is up to you, as long as it’s for personal use only. If in doubt, just get in touch. 

Original artwork:
If you are buying original artwork, please email me at cg.sketches@gmail.com before making a donation to make sure that the drawing you are interested in is still available. All drawings are individual pieces - once they are gone, they are gone. If you are outside the UK, please let me know so we can figure out if shipping is feasible.

All original drawings are black ink on sketching paper (some original also feature gold or other inks), signed in pencil. Original size is ca 208 x 290 mm. You can find photographs of the original drawings on instagram @goebelchristina

This is very slightly smaller than A4, I can keep the sketch paper in it’s original state (retaining rough sketchbook edges) or trim to a smaller size (e.g. 8 x 10 Inches) for you depending on preference. 

  1. Crystal (reserved)
  2. Suit
  3. Vessel (reserved)
  4. Knot 
  5. Raven
  6. Spirit
  7. Fan

  9. Pressure

  23. Leak

  30. Slither
  31. Risk (reserved)

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

If for any reason you’re not comfortable using JustGiving, feel free to email me your receipt to MSF instead.

We work in over 70 countries - in conflict zones, natural disasters and epidemics. We are independent, neutral and impartial. We provide medical care where it's needed most.
charity.name: Medecins Sans Frontieres / Doctors Without Borders (MSF)
story:
Friends of Médecins Sans Frontières Manchester are hosting an in-person Q+A with special guest - Brigitte Daubeny. This is a careers event aimed at helping students understand what it takes to work for an international aid organisation such as Doctors with Borders. 

Brigitte is MSF’s HR Officer, with her we plan to cover: what it is like working for an NGO, how to tailor your career towards humanitarian aid and how to make your application stand out! 

We also have two Doctors who have completed work for MSF talk as well. 

This live Q+A is taking place in Manchester Academy (Club Academy) on Tuesday 16th November 7:00-8:30pm!

Give us a follow at @uom_fomsf (Instagram) or @FoMSFmanchester (Facebook) for some sneak peaks!

Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is an independent international medical humanitarian organisation that delivers emergency aid in more than 60 countries to people affected by armed conflict, epidemics, natural or man-made disasters or exclusion from healthcare.

The Manchester Friends of MSF aim to support MSF by:

- Raising awareness of MSF's work around the world

- Fundraising

- Encouraging people to get involved with MSF

story:
5daygamers is back.

This will be the 15th event that we have done.

We started back in 2012. It's now 2021. This event is to raise money for MSF (Doctors without borders).

The event takes place from November 26th to 30th.

We have a pre stream on November 25th.

Streamers that are confirmed so far are - Evildeadfan102, Jessicayskull, RC3000, Endiku, Soapie Plays, Kingemocut, Hal Dimond and Donnabellez.

There will be plenty more as well.


I hope everyone enjoys the 5 days and remember to donate if you can.

We want to help as many people who are suffering due to Viruses, wars or natural disasters.

story:
Ythan Valley Rotary is running a "Decorated Christmas Tree Competition" for 2021. So many people had a disrupted Christmas last year we are keen to share as many photos of your beautifully decorated Christmas Trees as possible for 2021. As part of our International Fundraising we will be donating the money raised to WaterAid. A worthy and internationally recognised charity providing the very essentials to those most in need.

So send us a photo of your tree - inside or outside - along with your £5 donation on this site. Email on address below with your postcode or country. Open 1-20 December. We will post your entries on our Facebook page to show everyone your splendid efforts and will choose a worthy winner in each category by 20/12/21. Each winner will receive £10 and a hand made gift - and international acclaim too!

yvrdresstree@gmail.com

Ythan Valley Rotary on Facebook 

Water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.

charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Right now, some of the world’s poorest and most marginalised people don’t have clean water to drink, decent toilets or hygiene. Without these basics, overcoming poverty is just a dream.

But when you help WaterAid to dig a well or install a tap stand in a community, you're changing the lives of children for the better. They can dream again.

Every child should have a bright future ahead of them and focus on being a child - not walking long distances to collect and drink dirty water.

785 million people in the world – one in ten – do not have clean water close to home. WaterAid will keep working until everyone, everywhere has clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene. But they can’t do it without you.
title: Ben's page

charity.description: CARE International is one of the world’s leading aid agencies working in over 80 countries around the globe. We seek a world of hope, tolerance and social justice, with  women and girls at the centre, where poverty has been overcome, and people live with equal opportunities in security and dignity.
charity.name: CARE International UK
story:
Rising conflict in Afghanistan has left thousands of families displaced. 393,000 people have fled from their homes in the past month.

CARE is working around the clock to provide emergency assistance and cash to the most vulnerable families so they can get food, water and shelter. Since 1961, weve provided urgent humanitarian assistance in Afghanistan and will continue to protect and save lives with your help.

Emergency aid is absolutely necessary to save lives. Every penny will go to CAREs Emergency Response Fund  a dedicated fund, restricted solely for emergency response purposes within CARE International.
title: Afghanistan emergency appeal
